G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, as this is a civil action in tort seeking monetary relief within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, as this is a civil action in tort seeking monetary relief within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or operator of a child care or recreational facility owes a duty of reasonable care to protect invitees, particularly minor children, against foreseeable risks of harm.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused solely on proximate cause, not on defining the scope of a property owner’s duty toward invitees or children. While the underlying majority opinion in Mullins does recognize a duty of reasonable care by a college to protect a student from foreseeable criminal acts, that discussion is not present in this text, and the dissent does not challenge the existence of such a duty. Based only on the provided opinion text, the case excerpt does not itself establish or explain the duty described in the proposition.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving “that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.” Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).

Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.raw_text: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 452, 245 N.E.2d 420 (1969)
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or operator of a child care or recreational facility owes a duty of reasonable care to protect invitees, particularly minor children, against foreseeable risks of harm.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.case_name: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The case clearly recognizes that a bar/restaurant owner owes a duty of reasonable care to protect paying patrons from reasonably foreseeable harm caused by third persons, including intentional acts. However, the opinion says nothing about child care or recreational facilities, nor does it single out duties owed to minor children as invitees. It therefore supports a more general premises-liability duty to invitees, not the specific child-focused proposition stated.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant, as the operator of a restaurant and bar, was in possession of real estate open to the public for business purposes. It owed a duty to a paying patron to use reasonable care to prevent injury to him by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional. Restatement 2d: Torts, § 344.”

Poydras v. City of Boston, 19 Mass. App..raw_text: Poydras v. City of Boston, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 951 (1985)
Poydras v. City of Boston, 19 Mass. App..proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff’s minor son a duty to provide reasonable supervision commensurate with the children’s age and the activities undertaken.
Poydras v. City of Boston, 19 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the validity and enforcement of a municipal by-law requiring property owners to connect to a public sewer system. It does not involve tort duties, minors, supervision of children, or any standard of care owed by a defendant to a plaintiff’s minor child. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for a duty to provide reasonable supervision to children.
Poydras v. City of Boston, 19 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: The town brought this complaint seeking an injunction requiring certain landowners (of the type described in the by-law) to connect their buildings to the public sewer in the public way adjoining their respective parcels. Although the case was dismissed against some defendants who brought their properties into compliance with the by-law, a Superior Court judge correctly ordered summary judgment for the town against other defendants, who had not complied. The facts are not in dispute.

Mosko v. Raytheon Co., 416 Mass. 395 (19.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff’s minor son a duty to provide reasonable supervision commensurate with the children’s age and the activities undertaken.
Mosko v. Raytheon Co., 416 Mass. 395 (19.support_reasoning: The case concerns an employer’s potential liability as a social/employer host for injuries caused by an intoxicated employee, and whether any special duty arises from the employer‑employee relationship or control over alcohol. It does not involve minors, children, or any articulated duty to provide supervision commensurate with a child’s age or activities. The court actually declines to expand duties beyond those tied to control of the liquor supply, so it does not support a proposition about supervising a plaintiff’s minor son.
Mosko v. Raytheon Co., 416 Mass. 395 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Although, as a general rule, there is no duty to protect others from the negligent or wrongful acts of third parties, based on social values and customs, such a duty may be premised on the existence of a special relationship between the negligent person and the person or entity on whom it is sought to impose liability. … No such duty of care has been imposed, however, when a private defendant has not engaged in conduct that fairly might be described as negligent by furnishing alcohol to an obviously intoxicated person (or to a minor).”

Restatement (Second) of Torts \u00a7 314.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff’s minor son a duty to provide reasonable supervision commensurate with the children’s age and the activities undertaken.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 699 (2.proposition: Defendant breached its duty of care by failing to provide adequate staff supervision in the gymnasium, permitting older children to engage in unsafe play, and ignoring prior warnings of foreseeable danger.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 699 (2.support_reasoning: The case involves premises liability and negligence on a residential construction/roofing site, not supervision of children in a gymnasium or staffing levels. The court affirms summary judgment for the defendant because plaintiffs failed to prove causation or a breach of duty, and expressly notes there was no evidence the defendant knew of any hazardous condition. Nothing in the opinion discusses duties relating to staff supervision, control of children, or ignoring prior warnings of foreseeable dangerous play.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 699 (2.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. See Barry v. Beverly Enter-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 593 (1994) (landowner who has no actual or constructive knowledge of allegedly hazardous condition so that it cannot reasonably remove or warn plaintiff of the danger, cannot be found to have violated duty of care)."

Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.raw_text: Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp., 404 Mass. 624 (1989)
Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.proposition: Defendant breached its duty of care by failing to provide adequate staff supervision in the gymnasium, permitting older children to engage in unsafe play, and ignoring prior warnings of foreseeable danger.
Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s breach of duty by failing to supervise a gym, allow unsafe play by older children, and ignore prior warnings—essentially premises supervision in a school/gym setting. Yakubowicz involves a movie producer and theater owner’s alleged negligence relating to exhibiting a violent film and allowing a patron to consume alcohol, plus foreseeability of off‑premises violence. The court holds there was no breach of duty on these facts and does not address gymnasium supervision, older children’s unsafe play, or ignoring prior warnings in a premises‑liability/supervision context, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Yakubowicz v. Paramount Pictures Corp.,.relevant_excerpt: Count five of the complaint rests on the assertion that Saxon failed to exercise proper supervision and control over its patrons in that it permitted Barrett “to consume excessive amounts of alcoholic beverages and other intoxicants while viewing The Warriors,” and that, while under the influence of these intoxicants, Barrett killed the decedent. The judge properly entered summary judgment for Saxon on this count on the ground that Saxon did not owe the decedent a duty to protect him from acts resulting from Barrett’s self-induced intoxication.

Foley v. Bos. Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640.raw_text: Foley v. Bos. Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640 (1990)
Foley v. Bos. Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640.proposition: Defendant’s acts and omissions were unreasonable under all the circumstances and constituted negligence.
Foley v. Bos. Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640.support_reasoning: The case addresses negligence in terms of duty and foreseeability, but it ultimately holds that the defendants are not liable because the assault by the co-employee was not foreseeable and thus no duty was owed. The court affirms summary judgment for the defendants, explicitly finding that the harm was outside the scope of foreseeable risk. Therefore, this opinion does not support the proposition that the defendant’s acts and omissions were unreasonable under all the circumstances and constituted negligence; it supports the opposite conclusion.
Foley v. Bos. Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the attack by Ferris was outside the scope of the risk of foreseeable harm. ‘There is no duty owed when the risk which results in the plaintiff’s injury is not one which could be reasonably anticipated by the defendant.’… We are reluctant generally to take an issue of foreseeability away from a jury. However, this is one of the rare cases where it can be said that the harm which occurred was not within the scope of foreseeable risk to the victim. Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the court below.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the injuries suffered by Plaintiff’s minor son.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. Jupin v. Kask does not decide causation; it addresses only the existence of a duty and reverses summary judgment so a jury can determine breach and causation. The court explicitly treats causation as a jury question and does not hold that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the officer’s injuries.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

Mass. G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: As a direct and foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff’s minor son suffered physical injury, pain, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life, and Plaintiff incurred significant medical expenses.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F.proposition: As a direct and foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff’s minor son suffered physical injury, pain, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life, and Plaintiff incurred significant medical expenses.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award prejudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
